lines.text: I was going to thrash them within an inch of their lives, but I didn't have a tape measure.
I don't like your faces.
I suppose you think we like 'em.
You love your brother, don't you?
No, but I'm used to him.
Lulubelle, it's you! I didn't recognize you standing up.
[as Quale destroys Rusty's first hat]
Hey whataya do with that hat; that hat cost a lotta money.
How much did it cost him?
I dunno; he stole it.
[Indicating a gag around the train engineer's mouth]
Didya know this is the best gag in the picture?
[Chico suggests telephoning for help]
Telephone? This is 1870. Don Ameche hasn't invented the telephone yet!
Madam why is that baby constantly crying?
He can't stand the jerks in the coach.
the law of blood and bullets. It's either shoot or be shot. What are we gonna do?
Sue 'em!
My father-a shot the Indians in eighteen forty-two
Oh, he should-a shot the stork-a, when the stork-a brought-a you.

[dramatically]
Suppose I brought you back to my native land. What- what would my people say?
Burp.
Well, they'd phrase it more delicately.
Time wounds all heels.
Where have I seen your face before?
Right where it is now.

[Obviously intoxicated, commenting on his glass having just been shot in half by Baxter]
Less whiskey next time my glass can't take it.
[Arriving at the RR Station]
Any of you boys got change ah ten cents?
No.
Well, keep the baggage.
There's something corrupt going on around my pants but I just can't seem to locate it.
I give you my solemn word as an embezzler, I'll be back in ten minutes.
You know there's a drunk sitting at the first table who looks exactly like you? And one who looks exactly like me. Dull, isn't it?
Didn't we meet at Monte Carlo the night you blew your brains out?
You must fan the flames of love with the bellows of indifference.
Are you insinuating that the white man is not the Indian's friend? Ha! Who swindled you out of Manhattan Island for 24 dollars?
White man.
Who turned you into wood and stood you in front of a cigar store?
White man.
Who put your head on a nickel and then took the nickel away?
Slot machine.
Members of the tribe - I rest my case.
Now, this is the kind of hat they're wearing this season. This is the 1870 model. It's what they call a pioneer's cap.
[Put's the Daniel Boone hat, backwards, on 'Rusty']
Isn't that tail supposed to be in the back.
Not on him. That's genuine beaver.
It's pretty.
No, now I'll stroke it. It's still my hat, you know. That'll be ten dollars.
Ten dollars you want for that old beaver?
I'm not in business for love, you know. I was in love once and I got the business.
This is the last hat of it's kind. The beaver's have stopped making them. They're all out playing football. Ten dollars.
Well, he's a poor boy. He'll give you a dollar. Will you take it?
Well, I'll take it but I'm only making a buck on it.
You got to take some security. And I ain't got no security except a deed to Dead Man's Gulch.
Oh, no, we no take-a your land.

Oh, I'd feel better if you took it. Don't reckon its worth ten dollars, though. A fellow named Turner sold it to me about 40 year ago. Got me for my last cent. If you boys meet up with any Turner in this territory, shoot first.
First we steal his gun, then we shoot.
Rusty, I no like-a the West. All-a the people do is kill each other. I like-a the West better if it was in the East. Let's get outta here.
Where's my bustle? Where is it, anyway? Who has my bustle? Give me my bustle!
You said you was an embezzler, but, you no fool me. I knew you was a crook!
Let's go somewhere where we can be alone. Ah, there doesn't seem to be anyone on this couch.
Any resemblance between these two characters and living persons is purely accidental.
I'm not drunk, but, what's the ceiling doing on the floor?
It takes a smart man to know when he's licked. But, maybe between the two of you, there's enough brains to figure it out.
He's so full of alcohol, if you put a lighted wick in his mouth, he'd burn for three days.
See, you got the Chief mad! Let me talk to him.
Can you talk Indian?
I was born in Indianapolis!
Panello, this Indian is no Indian!
If he's no Indian, why is he wearin' a chicken for a hat?
Oh, stop it! Trying to pass yourself off as a red man. Why, you can't even speak the language. Let me hear you recite Hiawatha by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow.
Ugh.
That's not it.
If it is, they've shortened it since I went to school. And you call yourself a red man.
What did he say?
He said, first they're going to give us a fair trial, then they kill us.
White man talk too much. Make Chief heap mad.
White man, red man's friend. White man want to make friends with red brother.
And sister, too.
Chief like pale face who no talk. You pale face friend. Chief like you too.
Red man you're a white man.

[to an Indian squaw]
You get a canoe later and I'll paddle you.

[Noticing an attractive Indian girl has got Harpo all excited]
She gave him the Indian sign.

[pulls out a necklace]
How would you like a little necklace that formerly belonged to the Czarina of Russia?
No like. Me want Cadillac sedan.
*She's* been off the reservation...
[tosses necklace away]

[as Harpo and the Indian chief are having a completely unintelligible conversation]
You know, it's stimulating when two giant intellects get together.
